thread.title: Slidell Memorial Hospital CEO's salary made public after court battle
thread.title_full: Slidell Memorial Hospital CEO's salary made public after court battle | NOLA.com

author: Bob Warren, NOLA.com | The Times-Picayune
title: Slidell Memorial Hospital CEO's salary made public after court battle
text:
Slidell Memorial Hospital CEO Bill Davis had a $381,727 salary in 2014, a figure that was released by the Louisiana Legislative Auditor's office after a state judge rejected the hospital's bid to keep it from being publicly disclosed.
Following the ruling by state District Judge Janice Clark last week in Baton Rouge, the Auditor's Office released the full audit from 2014, with Davis' salary package included. In addition to the salary, Davis' insurance, retirement and other benefits pushed the total package to more than $460,000, the audit shows.
The Legislative Auditor's office said making the compensation public is a requirement of Act 706, which says that agencies being audited must include a supplemental report listing the CEO's compensation, including travel, housing, per diem, etc.
Bill Davis, CEO of Slidell Memorial Hospital Courtesy Slidell Memorial Hospital The 229-bed acute care community hospital sued the Legislative Auditor's office to block the release of the CEO salary, contending that information was part of the hospital's "marketing strategy'' and "strategic plan,'' which shields it from the public, the auditor's office said.
After Clark ruled in favor of the Legislative Auditor in August, the agency released the audit but withheld the information about the CEO's compensation. The hospital appealed Clark's ruling and sought a stay. But on Thursday (Sept. 17) she denied that motion and the Legislative Auditor released the full report.
Legislative Auditor Daryl Purpera said Clark's ruling confirms the Legislature's intent to let the public know "how much it is paying a public hospital's CEO in compensation, reimbursement and benefits.''
The hospital has argued that another legislative act, the Enhanced Ability to Compete Act, allows information such as salaries to be kept out of the public's view so as not to put it at a competitive disadvantage.
David Mannella, chairman of the hospital's Board of Commissioners, said the act "keeps a level playing field,'' between public hospitals and private hospitals, which do not have to publicly disclose such financial information. Mannella said the board wants to be "as transparent as possible,'' but has held that salaries are strategic information.
Manella said the board contracts with a consultant to help establish executive salaries and that the CEO's salary is based on those salaries paid by hospitals that have similar demographics.
